title: The Simplex Algorithm
text:
The simplex algorithm solves linear problems in their standard form, i.e., the following type of optimization problems: \[\begin{align}
    \min_{x \in \mathbb{R}^n} \; & c^T x
    \\
    \text{s.t.} \; & A x = b \tag{Primal}\label{eq_primal}
    \\
    & x \geq 0 \enspace,
\end{align}\] where \(c \in \mathbb{R}^n\), \(b \in \mathbb{R}^m\), and \(A \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}\).

title: The Simplex Algorithm
text:
The Optimality Conditions
The Karusk-Kuhn-Tucker optimality conditions write, there exists \(x \in \mathbb{R}^n, \lambda \in \mathbb{R}^m, \text{and } \mu \in \mathbb{R}^n\) such that: \[\begin{align}
    & A^T \lambda + \mu = c \tag{KKT-1}\label{eq-KKT1}
    \\
    & Ax = b
    \\
    & x \geq 0
    \\
    & \mu \geq 0
    \\
    & x_i \mu_i = 0 , \tag{Complementary Slackness}\label{eq-complslackness}
    \enspace \text{for } i \in 1, \dots, n
    \enspace .
\end{align}\] Since the problem is convex, with linear equality and inequality constraints, the Karusk-Kuhn-Tucker conditions are necessary and sufficient for being a solution of the linear problem. In other words, if one can find a triplet \((x, \lambda, \mu)\) that satisfies the KKT conditions, then \(x\) is an optimal point.

title: The Simplex Algorithm
text:
The Simplex Algorithm

Geometry of the Feasible Set

Definition 1 (Basic Feasible Point) 
\(x\) is a basic feasible point if there exists a basis \(\mathcal{B}\) such that

\(|\mathcal{B}| = m\)
\(x_{\mathcal{B}^c} = 0\), i.e., \(x_i = 0\) if \(i \notin \mathcal{B}\)
\(A_{:\mathcal{B}}\) is nonsingular, i.e., the square matrix \(A_{:\mathcal{B}}\) is full rank




Outline
Let’s start from a basic feasible point \(x \in \mathbb{R}^n\), and let’s try to find a triplet \((x, \lambda, \mu)\) that satisifies the KKT conditions.

\(x\) is a (non generated) basic feasible point, hence \(x_i \neq 0\) for \(i \in \mathcal{B}\), thus Equation \(\ref{eq-complslackness}\) yields \[\begin{align}
      \mu_i = 0 \text{ for } i \in \mathcal{B}
      \enspace.
  \end{align}\]
The latest equation combined with the Equation \(\ref{eq-KKT1}\) yields \[\begin{align}
  & A_{:\mathcal{B}}^T \lambda + \overbrace{\mu_{\mathcal{B}}}^{=0} = c_{\mathcal{B}}
  \\
  & \lambda = (A_{:\mathcal{B}}^T)^{-1} c_{\mathcal{B}}
  \enspace .
\end{align}\]
Pugging the value of \(\lambda\) in Equation \(\ref{eq-KKT1}\) restricted to \(\mathcal{B}\) yields \[\begin{align}
  \mu_{\mathcal{B}^c} = c_{\mathcal{B}^c} - A_{\mathcal{B}^c}^T (A_{:\mathcal{B}}^T)^{-1} c_{\mathcal{B}}^c
  \enspace .
\end{align}\]

Let’s recap: a (non degenerated) basic feasible point yields \(mu_{\mathcal{B}}=0\), which yields a unique dual variable \(\lambda\), which a unique slack variable $ _{^c}$. If in addition \(\mu\) satisfies \(\mu \geq 0\), then then triplet \((x, \lambda, \mu)\) satisfies the KKT condition
